elements.content: Competition between spin-crossover and structural ligand ordering is identified as responsible for multistability and generation of six different phases in a rigid two-dimensional coordination polymer formulated {FeII[HgII(SCN)3]2­μ-(4,4′-bipy)2} n (1) (4,4′-bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine). The structure of 1 consists of infinite linear [Fe­(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n 2n+ chains linked by in situ formed {[HgII(SCN)3]2­(μ-4,4′-bipy)}2n− anionic dimers. The thermal dependence of the high-spin fraction, γHS, features four magnetic phases defined by steps following the sequence γHS = 1 (phase 1) ↔ γHS = 1/2 (phase 2) ↔ γHS ≈ 1/3 (phase 3) ↔ γHS = 0 (phase 4). These four magnetic states are consistent with structural ordering stemming from the different commensurate or incommensurate high- and low-spin populations [HS] ↔ [HS:LS] ↔ ≈ [HS:2LS] ↔ [LS1] inferred from single crystal analysis. Furthermore, two additional phases are generated at low temperature. One, LS2 (γHS = 0, phase 5), is due to spontaneous symmetry breaking of the LS1 state below 85 K. The other results from irradiating the low-temperature LS2 phase at 15 K with red light to photogenerate a HS phase of low symmetry (HS*) (γHS = 1, phase 6). Detailed structural studies of the six phases unravel the pivotal role played by the internal dihedral angle of the 4,4′-bipy ligands in the microscopic mechanism responsible for multistability and multistep behavior in 1.

The structure of 1 consists of infinite linear [Fe(μ-4,4'-bipy)] n  2n+ chains linked by in situ formed {[HgII(SCN)3]2(μ-4,4'-bipy)}2n- anionic dimers. The thermal dependence of the high-spin fraction, γHS, features four magnetic phases defined by steps following the sequence γHS = 1 (phase 1) ↔ γHS = 1/2 (phase 2) ↔ γHS ~ 1/3 (phase 3) ↔ γHS = 0 (phase 4). These four magnetic states are consistent with structural ordering stemming from the different commensurate or incommensurate high- and low-spin populations [HS] ↔ [HS:LS] ↔ ~ [HS:2LS] ↔ [LS1] inferred from single crystal analysis. Furthermore, two additional phases are generated at low temperature. One, LS2 (γHS = 0, phase 5), is due to spontaneous symmetry breaking of the LS1 state below 85 K. The other results from irradiating the low-temperature LS2 phase at 15 K with red light to photogenerate a HS phase of low symmetry (HS*) (γHS = 1, phase 6). Detailed structural studies of the six phases unravel the pivotal role played by the internal dihedral angle of the 4,4'-bipy ligands in the microscopic mechanism responsible for multistability and multistep behavior in 1.

elements.content: Magnetostructural correlations in a multistable FeII−HgII heterometallic two-dimensional spin crossover coordination polymer discloses competing phases involving spin state and ligand structural ordering.
elements.clean_text: Magnetostructural correlations in a multistable FeII-HgII heterometallic two-dimensional spin crossover coordination polymer discloses competing phases involving spin state and ligand structural ordering.

elements.content: Iron­(II) spin crossover (SCO) complexes are switchable molecular materials that respond to environmental stimuli (T, P, light, analytes) through changes in magnetic, optical, electrical, and mechanical properties associated with the high- (HS) and low-spin (LS) states of the SCO center. The intrinsic on–off nature of the LS ↔ HS switch has attracted much interest not only because it constitutes an excellent platform for investigating models of thermal-, pressure, and photoinduced phase transitions in molecular materials but also because many expectancies have been created regarding the conception of SCO-based devices, i.e., sensors, actuators, and memories. This has led to an impressive growth of the SCO field in the past decade as a result of cross-seeding interactions between different areas of research ranging from coordination chemistry, materials science, and solid state physics.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Iron(II) spin crossover (SCO) complexes are switchable molecular materials that respond to environmental stimuli (T, P, light, analytes) through changes in magnetic, optical, electrical, and mechanical properties associated with the high- (HS) and low-spin (LS) states of the SCO center. The intrinsic on-off nature of the LS ↔ HS switch has attracted much interest not only because it constitutes an excellent platform for investigating models of thermal-, pressure, and photoinduced phase transitions in molecular materials but also because many expectancies have been created regarding the conception of SCO-based devices, i.e., sensors, actuators, and memories. This has led to an impressive growth of the SCO field in the past decade as a result of cross-seeding interactions between different areas of research ranging from coordination chemistry, materials science, and solid state physics.

elements.content: A pivotal current aspect that transcends the SCO research is the understanding of the elusive principles underlying cooperativity in multistep spin transitions in the solid state. Steps may occur when elastic forces favor competition between spatial periodicities of structural inequivalent SCO centers, for example, the presence of crystallographically distinct sites with different ligand field strengths. However, even if there is a unique SCO center in the crystal, inequivalence between SCO centers may spontaneously originate as a consequence of crystallographic symmetry breaking. Although crystallographic symmetry breaking giving intermediate steps was previously observed for the mononuclear SCO complexes [FeII{5-NO2-sal-N­(1,4,7,10)}] and {Fe­[HC­(3,5-Me2pz)3]2}­(BF4)2, its relevance in the field was disclosed investigating the nature of the two-step transition [0HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:0LS] in [FeII(2-pic)3]­Cl2­·EtOH. So far, a relatively small number of complete two-step or incomplete (only one step of two expected) SCO events with symmetry breaking have been observed in mononuclear, polynuclear, and polymeric FeII SCO complexes and reviewed recently. This phenomenology has also been described for a reduced number of FeIII, CoII, and MnIII complexes. Most of these examples exhibit spontaneous generation of a stable state characterized by a plateau at HS molar fraction γHS ≈ 1/2 and an ordered distribution of the HS and LS centers directly observed from single crystal X-ray analysis. In some rare cases the plateau and spontaneous ordering have been observed for γHS ≈ 2/3 and 1/3.

Steps may occur when elastic forces favor competition between spatial periodicities of structural inequivalent SCO centers, for example, the presence of crystallographically distinct sites with different ligand field strengths. However, even if there is a unique SCO center in the crystal, inequivalence between SCO centers may spontaneously originate as a consequence of crystallographic symmetry breaking. Although crystallographic symmetry breaking giving intermediate steps was previously observed for the mononuclear SCO complexes [FeII{5-NO2-sal-N(1,4,7,10)}] and {Fe[HC(3,5-Me2pz)3]2}(BF4)2, its relevance in the field was disclosed investigating the nature of the two-step transition [0HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:0LS] in [FeII(2-pic)3]Cl2⋅EtOH. So far, a relatively small number of complete two-step or incomplete (only one step of two expected) SCO events with symmetry breaking have been observed in mononuclear, polynuclear, and polymeric FeII SCO complexes and reviewed recently. This phenomenology has also been described for a reduced number of FeIII, CoII, and MnIII  complexes. Most of these examples exhibit spontaneous generation of a stable state characterized by a plateau at HS molar fraction γHS ~ 1/2 and an ordered distribution of the HS and LS centers directly observed from single crystal X-ray analysis. In some rare cases the plateau and spontaneous ordering have been observed for γHS ~ 2/3 and 1/3.

elements.content: Concatenation of several steps/plateaus in the same crystalline SCO material is an uncommon event, which conveys the concept of multistability. It is driven by the competition between short-range and long-range elastic interaction as a result of the molecular volume change between LS and HS states, responsible for the appearance of spin-state concentration waves (SSCW). Magnetic and Mössbauer studies have demonstrated the occurrence of three steps in the multicomponent mononuclear complex [FeII(dpp)2]­[Ni­(mnt)2]2­·MeNO2. The steps occur in the heating mode with intermediate plateaus at γHS ≈ 1/3 and 2/3 exhibiting the sequence [0HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:2LS] ↔ [2HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:0LS]. However, structural ordering could only be evidenced for step 1 where tripling of the unit, referring to the LS state, occurs in the plateau γHS ≈ 1/3 ([HS:2LS]). The 3D coordination polymer [FeII(dpsme)­Pt­(CN)4]­·2/3dpsme­·xEtOH­·yH2O displays a different three-step SCO with plateaus at γHS ≈ 1/3 and 1/2 consistent with the sequence [0HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:2LS] ↔ [1HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:0LS]. In going from γHS ≈ 1 (0HS:1LS) to γHS ≈ 1/2 (1HS:1LS) the unit cell of the latter compound changes from monoclinic (P2/a) to triclinic (P1̅), thus generating an ordered state were HS and LS layers alternate in the crystal. In a subsequent step the system attains a new ordering state at γHS ≈ 1/3 (1HS:2LS) doubling the triclinic unit cell. The 3D and 2D coordination polymers [FeII(bipydz)­(AuI(CN)2)2]­·x(EtOH) (bipydz = 3,6-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2-diazine) and the two-dimensional (2D) [Fe3 II(saltrz)6­(MII(CN)4)3]­·8­(H2O) (MII = Pd, Pt; saltrz = (E)-2-(((4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)­imino)­methyl)­phenol) represent the first examples of four step SCO where ordering in each step has been structurally characterized. The first system displays the singular sequence of steps [0HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:2LS] ↔ [1HS:1LS] ↔ [2HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:0LS] with γHS ≈ 0, 1/3, 1/2, 2/3, and 1, respectively, while the sequence for the second system is different [0HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:2LS] ↔ [2HS:1LS] ↔ [5HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:0LS], which corresponds to γHS ≈ 0, 2/6, 4/6, 5/6, and 1, respectively.

elements.content: In a recent communication, we concisely introduced the 2D bimetallic SCO coordination polymer formulated {FeII[(HgII­(SCN)3]2μ­(4,4′bipy)2} n (1) as a new relevant example of three-step SCO with [0HS:1LS] ↔ ≈ [1HS:2LS] ↔ [1HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:0LS] sequence. This sequence displays successive symmetry breaking transitions and HS–LS ordering associated with each plateau, which have been rationalized in the framework of SCO devil’s staircase behavior. In this context, the plateau at γHS ≈ 1/2 was described as a commensurate HS–LS SSCW characterized by a locked modulation wave-vector Q c = 1/2a* + 1/2b* + 1/2c* generating a ···HS–LS–HS–LS··· order (1HS:1LS state), while, by contrast, the plateau at γHS ≈ 1/3 corresponds to an incommensurate SSCW with a modulation vector evolving around q i = 0.48a* + 0.35b* + 0.42c*. Consequently, the modulation of the spatial population of HS and LS molecular states is incommensurate with the molecular lattice, and the global sequence of molecular states is aperiodic.
elements.clean_text: In a recent communication, we concisely introduced the 2D bimetallic SCO coordination polymer formulated {FeII[(HgII(SCN)3]2μ(4,4'bipy)2} n  (1) as a new relevant example of three-step SCO with [0HS:1LS] ↔ ~ [1HS:2LS] ↔ [1HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:0LS] sequence. This sequence displays successive symmetry breaking transitions and HS-LS ordering associated with each plateau, which have been rationalized in the framework of SCO devil's staircase behavior. In this context, the plateau at γHS ~ 1/2 was described as a commensurate HS-LS SSCW characterized by a locked modulation wave-vector Q c = 1/2a* + 1/2b* + 1/2c* generating a ⋅⋅⋅HS-LS-HS-LS⋅⋅⋅ order (1HS:1LS state), while, by contrast, the plateau at γHS ~ 1/3 corresponds to an incommensurate SSCW with a modulation vector evolving around q  i  = 0.48a* + 0.35b* + 0.42c*. Consequently, the modulation of the spatial population of HS and LS molecular states is incommensurate with the molecular lattice, and the global sequence of molecular states is aperiodic.

elements.content: To characterize this remarkable system in depth, here we report on its magnetic and photomagnetic properties, relaxation kinetics, as well as detailed description of the crystal structure of 1 in the states γHS = 1 (1HS:0LS) (phase 1), 1/2 (1HS:1LS) (phase 2), ≈1/3 (≈1HS:2LS) (phase 3), 0 (0HS:1LS) (phases 4 and 5), and the photoinduced HS state (HS*) (phase 6). We have found that, in addition to the aforementioned commensurable and incommensurable spin-state ordering symmetry breaking on the plateaus, other types of symmetry breaking due to ligand ordering occurs at low temperature. The LS state displays a pure crystallographic transition around 85 K. The high-symmetry LS1 phase 4 at 90 K is isostructural to the HS phase at 220 K, while below 85 K the structure loses symmetry with doubling of the unit cell due to ligand ordering (LS2) (phase 5). Interestingly, the photogenerated HS* state at 15 K preserves this unit cell doubling, thus generating a photoinduced metastable of lower symmetry than the HS state reached at high temperature at thermal equilibrium.

elements.content: The thermal dependence of χM T product (χM = magnetic susceptibility, T = temperature) of 1 is shown in a. In the interval 300–190 K, χM T ≈ 3.67 cm3 K mol–1 is practically constant and consistent with a FeII HS (S = 2) (phase 1). Below 170 K, χM T drops rapidly in a first step, reaching a first plateau in the temperature interval 125–108 K. On the plateau ca. 50% of HS → LS conversion (χM T ≈ 1.90 cm3 K mol–1 at 119 K) takes place (phase 2). On cooling further, a second drop occurs and another plateau is reached in the interval 108–96 K, which corresponds almost to ca. 66% of conversion (χM T ≈ 1.33 cm3 K mol–1) (phase 3). Finally, a third sharp drop occurs around 96 K and attains a value of χM T ≈ 0.1 cm3 K mol–1 at 93 K where the conversion toward the LS state is almost complete (phase 4). The heating mode reproduces the three steps, but the two low-temperature transitions occur at T c’s ca. 4–6 K higher than in the cooling mode (two cycles performed at scan temperature rates of 0.5 and 1 K min–1). This three-step transition corresponds rather well to the sequence [0HS:1LS] ↔ ≈ [1HS:2LS] ↔ [1HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:0LS]. It is worth stressing that this magnetic behavior is perfectly reproducible after a great number of cycles and that the samples (single crystals) are very stable.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Magnetic and Photomagnetic Data

The thermal dependence of χM T product (χM = magnetic susceptibility, T = temperature) of 1 is shown in a. In the interval 300-190 K, χM T ~ 3.67 cm3 K mol-1 is practically constant and consistent with a FeII HS (S = 2) (phase 1). Below 170 K, χM T drops rapidly in a first step, reaching a first plateau in the temperature interval 125-108 K. On the plateau ca. 50% of HS → LS conversion (χM T ~ 1.90 cm3 K mol-1 at 119 K) takes place (phase 2). On cooling further, a second drop occurs and another plateau is reached in the interval 108-96 K, which corresponds almost to ca. 66% of conversion (χM T ~ 1.33 cm3 K mol-1) (phase 3). Finally, a third sharp drop occurs around 96 K and attains a value of χM T ~ 0.1 cm3 K mol-1 at 93 K where the conversion toward the LS state is almost complete (phase 4). The heating mode reproduces the three steps, but the two low-temperature transitions occur at T c's ca. 4-6 K higher than in the cooling mode (two cycles performed at scan temperature rates of 0.5 and 1 K min-1). This three-step transition corresponds rather well to the sequence [0HS:1LS] ↔ ~ [1HS:2LS] ↔ [1HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:0LS]. It is worth stressing that this magnetic behavior is perfectly reproducible after a great number of cycles and that the samples (single crystals) are very stable.

elements.content: (a) Magnetic and photomagnetic properties of compound 1 (blue and red triangles correspond, respectively, to the cooling and heating modes. Orange line corresponds to irradiation of the sample at 10 K (see text). Labels 1–6 locate the different crystallographic phases. (b) Relaxation curves at different temperatures of the photogenerated HS* state (red lines correspond to the best fit). (c) Arrhenius plot.

elements.content: Photogeneration of the metastable HS* state at low temperature, the so-called light induced excited spin state trapping experiment (LIESST), was carried out on a microcrystalline sample (2.76 mg) of 1 (a). The sample was cooled down to 10 K where χM T ≈ 0.09 cm3 K mol–1. Then the sample was irradiated with red light (λ = 633 nm) rapidly attaining (less than 30′) a saturation χM T value ca. 3.0 cm3 K mol–1. Light irradiation was then switched off, and the temperature increased at a rate of 0.3 K min–1. In the 10–38 K temperature range χM T increased up to a maximum value ca. 3.40 cm3 K mol–1 at 38 K, which reflects thermal population of the different microstates arising from the zero-field splitting of the HS* (S = 2) state and suggests that the light-induced population of the HS* state is virtually complete at 10 K (phase 6). At temperatures greater than 39 K, χM T drops rapidly and reaches a value about 0.09 cm3 K mol–1 at ca. 62 K indicating complete HS* → LS relaxation. The T LIESST temperature determined from the maximum variation of χM T in the HS → LS relaxation is equal to 54 K.
elements.clean_text: Photogeneration of the metastable HS* state at low temperature, the so-called light induced excited spin state trapping experiment (LIESST), was carried out on a microcrystalline sample (2.76 mg) of 1 (a). The sample was cooled down to 10 K where χM T ~ 0.09 cm3 K mol-1. Then the sample was irradiated with red light (λ = 633 nm) rapidly attaining (less than 30') a saturation χM T value ca. 3.0 cm3 K mol-1. Light irradiation was then switched off, and the temperature increased at a rate of 0.3 K min-1. In the 10-38 K temperature range χM T increased up to a maximum value ca. 3.40 cm3 K mol-1 at 38 K, which reflects thermal population of the different microstates arising from the zero-field splitting of the HS* (S = 2) state and suggests that the light-induced population of the HS* state is virtually complete at 10 K (phase 6). At temperatures greater than 39 K, χM T drops rapidly and reaches a value about 0.09 cm3 K mol-1 at ca. 62 K indicating complete HS* → LS relaxation. The T LIESST temperature determined from the maximum variation of χM T in the HS → LS relaxation is equal to 54 K.

elements.content: The HS* → LS relaxation kinetics has been investigated in the temperature interval 30–56 K (b). In the region 56–42.5 K, the curves were reasonably well-simulated using two equally weighed exponential functions. Because the relaxation is significantly reduced, only a simple exponential was used at lower temperatures. From derived k 1 and k 2 values, gathered in Table S1, and the corresponding Arrhenius plot in the interval 56–42.5 K (c) the pre-exponential factors k i(T → ∞) = 21 (1) and 38 (2) s–1 and the activation energies E a i = 527 (1) and 440 (2) cm–1 have been estimated. These values are consistent with other related SCO compounds. Usually, these parameters are largely underestimated due to coexistence of tunneling and thermal activation in the 30–50 K temperature range. Observation of a biexponential kinetic regime could be consistent with the formation of an ordered intermediate HS*–LS phase and its subsequent relaxation to the LS state. However, although the χM T vs T plot shows a slight change of slope, there is no a clear plateau at ca. 50% of relaxation (even irradiating for 12 h). In this respect, a recent theoretical study underlined that the step may hardly appear during the relaxation process because the long-range HS–LS order difficultly forms.

elements.content: Single crystal diffraction data have been recorded in the different phases at 220 K, 117 K, 102 K, 90 K, 80 K, 15 K, and at 15 K after irradiation with a red laser (λ = 660 nm). , Table S2 and Table S3 gather relevant crystal data and selected bond distances and angles, respectively. The unit cell of 1 is triclinic P1̅ at whatever temperature. From a crystallographic point of view, the thermal dependence of the unit cell volume, V, reproduces reasonably well the χM T vs T plot (Figure S1) during cooling and heating. While heating the sample from phase 5 to phase 1, we observe the same structural reorganizations on the steps. The phase transition from phase 5 to 4 is continuous, so the symmetry change occurs at 85 K in both cases. The phase transition from phase 4 to 3 occurs at almost the same temperature in the heating and cooling modes, as observed by volume change and appearance of satellite peaks. In the same way, the phase transition from phase 3 to 2 occurs around 108 K in both cases. The difference in thermal behavior between X-ray and magnetism between phase 4 and 2 is due to kinetics effects as magnetic curves were recorded with 0.3 K/min ramp, whereas X-ray data were collected with a ramp of ∼0.1 K/min. The crystals display marked thermochromism associated with the SCO. They reversibly change from light-orange at room temperature (HS state) to deep-red (LS state) at liquid nitrogen temperature. This drastic change of color is due to the presence of relatively intense 1A1 → 1T1 and 1A1 → 1T2 absorptions characteristic of the LS state and the lack of strong charge-transfer bands (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text:
Variable Temperature Single Crystal Analysis

Single crystal diffraction data have been recorded in the different phases at 220 K, 117 K, 102 K, 90 K, 80 K, 15 K, and at 15 K after irradiation with a red laser (λ = 660 nm). , Table S2 and Table S3 gather relevant crystal data and selected bond distances and angles, respectively. The unit cell of 1 is triclinic P1̅ at whatever temperature. From a crystallographic point of view, the thermal dependence of the unit cell volume, V, reproduces reasonably well the χM T vs T plot (Figure S1) during cooling and heating. While heating the sample from phase 5 to phase 1, we observe the same structural reorganizations on the steps. The phase transition from phase 5 to 4 is continuous, so the symmetry change occurs at 85 K in both cases. The phase transition from phase 4 to 3 occurs at almost the same temperature in the heating and cooling modes, as observed by volume change and appearance of satellite peaks. In the same way, the phase transition from phase 3 to 2 occurs around 108 K in both cases. The difference in thermal behavior between X-ray and magnetism between phase 4 and 2 is due to kinetics effects as magnetic curves were recorded with 0.3 K/min ramp, whereas X-ray data were collected with a ramp of ~0.1 K/min. The crystals display marked thermochromism associated with the SCO. They reversibly change from light-orange at room temperature (HS state) to deep-red (LS state) at liquid nitrogen temperature. This drastic change of color is due to the presence of relatively intense 1A1 → 1T1 and 1A1 → 1T2 absorptions characteristic of the LS state and the lack of strong charge-transfer bands (Figure S2).

At 220 K, there is a single FeII site lying on an inversion center. The asymmetric unit consists of one axially coordinated N atom belonging to a 4,4′-bipy ligand (Fe–N1 = 2.183(3) Å) and two equatorial N atoms belonging to two crystallographically distinct NCS groups (Fe–N2 = 2.153(3) and Fe–N3 = 2.137(3)) (). The average Fe1–N bond length of the slightly distorted [FeIIN6] octahedron, <Fe1–N> = 2.158(3) Å, is consistent with the FeII atom in the HS state, in agreement with the χM T value at same temperature. The small distortion of the [FeIIN6] octahedron is also reflected in the sum of deviations, from the ideal octahedron, of the 12 “cis” N–Fe–N angles, Σoct = ∑ i = 1 12|θ i – 90°|) = 11.24°.

elements.content: Two consecutive FeII centers are bridged by a strictly planar 4,4′-bipy ligand lying on an inversion center, thereby defining [Fe­(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n 2n+ chains running along the [010] direction. These chains are slightly undulated since two consecutive FeII are alternatively situated ca. 0.42 Å above and below the plane defined by the 4,4′-bipy. One of the thiocyanate ligands is essentially linear, N3–C7–S2 = 179.1(3)°, while the other, N2–C6–S1, separates 3.7° (average) from linearity due to positional disorder shown by the S1 atom. The Fe–N­(−C–S) bonds are almost collinear showing a slight off-axis tilt of 4.1° for Fe–N3–C7–S2 and 5.8° (average) for Fe–N2–C6–S1.

The Fe-N(-C-S) bonds are almost collinear showing a slight off-axis tilt of 4.1° for Fe-N3-C7-S2 and 5.8° (average) for Fe-N2-C6-S1.

elements.content: The charge of the [Fe­(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n 2n+ chains is balanced by in situ generated centrosymmetric {[HgII(SCN)3]2­(μ-4,4′-bipy)}2– dimeric moieties constituted of two strongly distorted tetrahedral [HgIIS3N] coordination sites. The sum of deviations, from the ideal tetrahedron, of the six “cis” angles around the Hg ion, Σtet = ∑ i = 1 6|θ i – 109.5°|) = 79.2° confirms the strong distortion from the regular geometry (a). The tetrahedrons are linked through a second crystallographically independent 4,4′-bipy ligand (Hg–N5 = 2.407(3) Å), which is also strictly planar. The Hg–S­(−C–N) bonds are strongly tilted [Hg–S3–C8–N4, 98.5°; Hg–S2–C7–N3, 93.7°; Hg–S1–C6–N2, 104.1° (average)]. One thiocyanate, N4–C8–S3 (Hg–S3 = 2.4253(11) Å), acts as a terminal ligand, while the other two, N3–C7–S2 (Hg–S2 = 2.5152(10) Å) and N2–C6–S1 (average Hg–S1 = 2.56(3) Å), act as bis-monodentate bridging ligands coordinating the equatorial positions of the Fe sites of consecutive [Fe­(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n 2n+ chains, thus defining infinite layers which stack along the [100] direction (b). Between two consecutive layers there are very few relevant contacts, i.e., C8···C12′ = 3.611(5), C8···C8′ = 3.513(5) Å, C6···S2 = 3.457(6).

elements.content: In the 108–125 K plateau, the unit cell doubles along (a + b + c) displaying characteristic superstructure Bragg peaks at Q c1 = 1/2 a * + 1/2 b * + 1/2 c * (). A fragment of the structure in this doubled cell together with the atom numbering of the asymmetric unit is displayed in a. The structural refinement of the double cell at 117 K reveals the occurrence of two distinct centrosymmetric FeII sites: site 1 with < Fe1–N > ≈ 1.968(3) Å and (Σoct)1 = 5.5° is mainly LS, while site 2 with <Fe2–N> ≈ 2.146(3) Å and (Σoct)2 = 15.5° is mainly HS. As a consequence, the 4,4′-bipy ligands lose the planarity and consequently the inversion center in the slightly undulating [Fe­(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n 2n+ chains. The twist angle, ϕ, defined by the two pyridyl rings of the 4,4′-bipy ligand is 3.5° (see ). Besides, there are two crystallographically distinct centrosymmetric {[HgII(SCN)3]2­(μ-4,4′-bipy)}2– units which show little differences with respect to the 220 K structure. Their 4,4′-bipy ligands keep the inversion centers and remain planar, ϕ′ = 0 (), and the coordination spheres of Hg1 and Hg2 are strongly distorted with (Σtet)i values of 87.35° and 75.05°, respectively. The 2D network accommodates the changes associated with the SCO at Fe1 through small readjustments, which mainly involve angular changes in the [HgNS3] and [Fe2N6] cores, i.e., (Σtet,oct)i changes by +8.5° and −4.1° for Hg1 and Hg2 centers, and by +4.2° for Fe2-center in comparison to the geometry of phase 1. The Fe-NCS tilt angles found in the range 3.8–5° remain practically unaltered.

elements.content: Within the 2D network, the sites Fe1­(LS) and Fe2­(HS) alternate affording an ordered chessboard-like state (b). The crystal packing consists of a pile of networks along [101] and defines slices of HS and LS layers alternating along [001] (c). With respect to the crystalline lattice of the HS phase, this situation can be described as the formation of a spin-state concentration plane wave along the wave vector Q c1 = 1/2 a * + 1/2 b * + 1/2 c *, which is commensurate with the initial ( a* , b* , c* ) reciprocal lattice. The crystal structure consists then of mainly HS and LS stripes alternating in a···HS–LS–HS–LS··· sequence along Q c1.

The crystal packing consists of a pile of networks along [101] and defines slices of HS and LS layers alternating along [001] (c). With respect to the crystalline lattice of the HS phase, this situation can be described as the formation of a spin-state concentration plane wave along the wave vector Q c1 = 1/2 a * + 1/2 b * + 1/2 c *, which is commensurate with the initial ( a* , b* , c* ) reciprocal lattice. The crystal structure consists then of mainly HS and LS stripes alternating in a⋅⋅⋅HS-LS-HS-LS⋅⋅⋅ sequence along Q c1.

elements.content: Upon cooling, a new symmetry change takes place on the 96–108 K step. The Bragg peaks at Q c1 characteristic of the formation of the commensurate SSCW disappear, whereas new peaks appear at Q = ha* + kb* + lc* + mq i with q i = α a* + β b* + γ c* (). Since α ≈ 0.48(1), β ≈ 0.35(1), and γ ≈ 0.42(1) cannot be expressed as simple fractions the crystalline structure is no more 3D periodic, but incommensurately modulated with respect to the HS (a,b,c) lattice. It belongs to the 4D superspace group P1̅(α,β,γ)­0 (SSG number 2.1.1.1). The structural analysis shows that the average 3D periodic cell is similar to the HS lattice. The structure is characterized by a unique Fe1 site with <Fe1–N> = 2.025(9) Å and Σ1 = 9.3°. The corresponding average bond length change Δ­(<Fe–N>) = (2.058–2.024) = 0.034 Å represents ca. 17–16% of additional HS → LS transformation, which agrees well with the estimated change observed from χM T (ca. 16%). The overall transformation is consistent with γHS ≈ 1/3 found in magnetic measurements. Unlike other previous examples with γHS ≈ 1/3, this state does not correspond to a unit cell tripling with ordering, e.g., LS–LS–HS, as the new Bragg peaks are at incommensurate positions. The crystal structure refinement in the 4D superspace group P1̅(α,β,γ)­0 explains the ordering on this step. In the full structure model of a modulated structure, the atoms must be described by their positions in the average (a,b,c) 3D unit cell and by their modulation functions along the fourth dimension coordinate x4 of the superspace.

elements.content: The modulation of the <Fe–N> bond length along x 4, as seen in (bottom), characterizes the presence of stripes of HS and LS molecular states, perpendicular to the direction of the incommensurate modulation vector q i , i.e., of a SSCW incommensurate with the ( a , b , c ) lattice. Here, the torsion angles, τ and τ′, defined respectively by the 4,4′-bipy ligands of the {[HgII(SCN)3]2­(μ-4,4′-bipy)}2– and [Fe­(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n 2n+ moieties are also modulated along x 4, underlying that the spin-state ordering is accompanied by a ligand ordering (top and middle). In this incommensurate phase due to the modulations, both ϕ and ϕ′ angles are given in their average representation. They are no planar () due to the loss of the inversion centers on the 4,4′-bipy ligands for Fe- and Hg-moieties.

elements.content: The crystal structure in the LS state has been investigated at 90 K, 80 K, and 15 K. At 90 K the crystal remains triclinic with a (a,b,c) cell similar to the one of the HS phase: the total volume contraction of the unit cell ΔV c in the 220–90 K interval is 41.45 Å3 (Figure S1). This value corresponds to the sum of the volume change due to thermal expansion (ΔV(T) ≈ V HS·αV·T) and SCO (ΔV SCO). From the thermal dependence of the unit cell volume in the temperature range 172–250 K, where γHS is constant and ≈1, the volumetric thermal expansion coefficient, αv = (1/V)­(∂V∂T), is estimated to be in the interval 1.4–1.8 × 10–4 K–1 and then ΔV SCO is about 28.2 Å3 (see thermal variation of the cell volume and lattice parameters a, b, and c both in cooling and heating modes respectively in Figures S1 and S3). These values correspond well with what it is expected for a complete HS–LS transformation for one FeII center (LS1 state). The structure consists of a single Fe site, and its average Fe–N bond length <Fe1–N> = 1.961(3) Å and the angular distortion (Σoct)1 = 7.6° and the overall Δd(Fe–N) = 0.197(3) Å bond length change upon SCO are fully consistent with a LS state. Apart from these changes, the 90 K structure does not present other relevant differences with respect to the structure at 220 K (Figure S4). For example, (i) at both temperatures the assymmetric unit is the same; (ii) both crystallographically distinct 4,4′-bipy bridging ligands become again planar, ϕ = ϕ′ = 0; (iii) the deviation from 180° of the NCS– groups decreases a little being the largest separation 2.7° for S1–C6–N2; (iv) the tilt angle of the Fe-NCS moiety is smaller by ca. 2°; and (v) Σtet for Hg is virtually the same (75.7°). Similarly, the interaction between two consecutive layers is only modified a little: C8···C8i = 3.432(6) Å, C8···C13i = 3.661(6) Å, C8···C12i = 3.571(6) Å, and C6···S2i = 3.485(6) Å.

At 90 K the crystal remains triclinic with a (a,b,c) cell similar to the one of the HS phase: the total volume contraction of the unit cell ΔV c in the 220-90 K interval is 41.45 Å3 (Figure S1). This value corresponds to the sum of the volume change due to thermal expansion (ΔV(T) ~ V HS⋅αV⋅T) and SCO (ΔV SCO). From the thermal dependence of the unit cell volume in the temperature range 172-250 K, where γHS is constant and ~1, the volumetric thermal expansion coefficient, αv = (1/V)(∂V∂T), is estimated to be in the interval 1.4-1.8 × 10-4 K-1 and then ΔV SCO is about 28.2 Å3 (see thermal variation of the cell volume and lattice parameters a, b, and c both in cooling and heating modes respectively in Figures S1 and S3). These values correspond well with what it is expected for a complete HS-LS transformation for one FeII center (LS1 state). The structure consists of a single Fe site, and its average Fe-N bond length <Fe1-N> = 1.961(3) Å and the angular distortion (Σoct)1 = 7.6° and the overall Δd(Fe-N) = 0.197(3) Å bond length change upon SCO are fully consistent with a LS state. Apart from these changes, the 90 K structure does not present other relevant differences with respect to the structure at 220 K (Figure S4). For example, (i) at both temperatures the assymmetric unit is the same; (ii) both crystallographically distinct 4,4'-bipy bridging ligands become again planar, ϕ = ϕ' = 0; (iii) the deviation from 180° of the NCS- groups decreases a little being the largest separation 2.7° for S1-C6-N2; (iv) the tilt angle of the Fe-NCS moiety is smaller by ca. 2°; and (v) Σtet for Hg is virtually the same (75.7°). Similarly, the interaction between two consecutive layers is only modified a little: C8⋅⋅⋅C8i = 3.432(6) Å, C8⋅⋅⋅C13i = 3.661(6) Å, C8⋅⋅⋅C12i = 3.571(6) Å, and C6⋅⋅⋅S2i = 3.485(6) Å.

elements.content: The 80 and 15 K LS structures are essentially identical and denote the occurrence of a pure crystallographic symmetry breaking phase transition, associated with a different type of unit-cell doubling, characterized by the appearance of Bragg peaks at Q c2 = 1/2 b * + 1/2 c * below 85 K (e). A representation of the asymmetric unit at 80–15 K is given in Figure S5. In the double unit cell the [Fe­(μ-4,4′-bipy)] n 2n+ chains are defined by non-centrosymmetric FeII sites linked by planar centrosymmetric 4,4′-bipy bridges, ϕ = 0, while the {[HgII(SCN)3]2­(μ-4,4′-bipy)}2– units are constituted of two crystallographically distinct HgII(1,2) centers bridged by a non-centrosymmetric 4,4′-bipy bridge, whose pyridine rings form mutual twist angles ϕ′1,2 in the interval 12.3–16.7°. displays a fragment of a layer with the lost and remaining symmetry centers mapped. Furthermore, the angular distortion of the Hg coordination sphere, (Σtet)1 ≈ 81° and (Σtet)2 ≈ 86.1° for Hg1 and Hg2 respectively, is remarkably different with respect to the 90 K structure. Nevertheless, these values compensate each other to give an average similar to the one found at 90 K.
elements.clean_text:
Phase 5, γHS ~ 0, Low Symmetry LS2 Structure

The 80 and 15 K LS structures are essentially identical and denote the occurrence of a pure crystallographic symmetry breaking phase transition, associated with a different type of unit-cell doubling, characterized by the appearance of Bragg peaks at Q c2 = 1/2 b * + 1/2 c * below 85 K (e). A representation of the asymmetric unit at 80-15 K is given in Figure S5. In the double unit cell the [Fe(μ-4,4'-bipy)] n  2n+ chains are defined by non-centrosymmetric FeII sites linked by planar centrosymmetric 4,4'-bipy bridges, ϕ = 0, while the {[HgII(SCN)3]2(μ-4,4'-bipy)}2- units are constituted of two crystallographically distinct HgII(1,2) centers bridged by a non-centrosymmetric 4,4'-bipy bridge, whose pyridine rings form mutual twist angles ϕ'1,2 in the interval 12.3-16.7°.  displays a fragment of a layer with the lost and remaining symmetry centers mapped. Furthermore, the angular distortion of the Hg coordination sphere, (Σtet)1 ~ 81° and (Σtet)2 ~ 86.1° for Hg1 and Hg2 respectively, is remarkably different with respect to the 90 K structure. Nevertheless, these values compensate each other to give an average similar to the one found at 90 K.

elements.content: After irradiation at 15 K the LS single crystal becomes HS, as observed with the color change. However, the photogenerated HS state, HS*, retains the same low-symmetry structure described for the LS state at 80 and 15 K with a doubled unit cell characterized by the appearance of Bragg peaks at Q c2 = 1/2 b * + 1/2 c * with respect to the HS phase reached at thermal equilibrium. The unit cell contains one non-centrosymmetric FeII site with average Fe–N bond length slightly smaller, <Fe1–N> = 2.141(3) Å, than that of the HS state at 220 K (probably due to incomplete conversion of the crystal) but similar Σoct = 11.3° value. There are also two distinct HgII centers linked by non-centrosymmetric 4,4′-bipy bridges which differ in Hg–S bond lengths and Hg­(1,2) (Σtet) i values. A superposition of the HS (220 K) and HS* (15 K) exactly maps the same distribution of retained and lost inversion centers shown in for the LS states.

The unit cell contains one non-centrosymmetric FeII site with average Fe-N bond length slightly smaller, <Fe1-N> = 2.141(3) Å, than that of the HS state at 220 K (probably due to incomplete conversion of the crystal) but similar Σoct = 11.3° value. There are also two distinct HgII centers linked by non-centrosymmetric 4,4'-bipy bridges which differ in Hg-S bond lengths and Hg(1,2) (Σtet) i  values. A superposition of the HS (220 K) and HS* (15 K) exactly maps the same distribution of retained and lost inversion centers shown in  for the LS states.

elements.content: Compound 1 represents the first member of a new family of 2D SCO coordination polymers constituted of in situ generated {[HgII(SCN)3]2­(μ-4,4′-bipy)} building blocks. Furthermore, as far as we know, this compound represents the first example in which four NCS– groups occupy the equatorial positions of a SCO [FeIIN6] chromophore, while the axial positions are occupied by a pyridine-like ligand. Usually, the opposite situation is the commonly observed in SCO complexes. Indeed, one should not expect SCO behavior for a {FeII(NCS)4­(pyridine-like)} n moiety because the ligand field strength of the NCS– is smaller than that of common pyridine-like ligands, and hence the HS state should be the ground state at all temperatures. This is particularly true for 4,4′bipy; for example, the 1D compound [FeII(4,4′bipy)­(bt)­(NCS)2] combining a bridging 4,4′bipy with the medium-strong α-diimine bidentate ligand 2,2′-bithiazoline (bt) and two cis-NCS– anions remains essentially HS at all temperatures. Similarly, in the 2D coordination polymer [Fe­(4,4′bipy)2­(NCS)2]­·nSolvent the FeII is equatorially surrounded by four bridging 4,4′bipy ligands and two terminal trans-NCS– groups but remains HS for a representative series of solvents and even the unsolvated derivate. The HS persists when increasing the ligand field strength replacing NCS– with the [Ag­(CN)2]− anion to form the Hofmann-like 3D coordination polymer {FeII(4,4′bipy)2­[Ag­(CN)2]2}. The only exception in this series corresponds to the [Fe­(4,4′bipy)2­(NCX)2]­·nSolvent system when nSolvent = 4CHCl3. For X = S the compound displays a cooperative two-step transition in the interval of temperatures 80–160 K, while for X = Se only a half cooperative SCO occurs centered at ca. 160 K. The presence of four densely packed CHCl3 molecules around the FeII sites provides enough chemical pressure to observe SCO in both derivatives. Similarly, we invoke the occurrence of an effective ligand field strength stemming from the rigid and densely packed layers to explain the observation of SCO in 1. On one hand, the resulting strong elastic interaction may induce mechanical frustration responsible for the formation of long-range order HS and LS states of different molecular volume. On the other hand, the thermal contraction increases the molecular packing and drives ligand ordering.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Compound 1 represents the first member of a new family of 2D SCO coordination polymers constituted of in situ generated {[HgII(SCN)3]2(μ-4,4'-bipy)} building blocks. Furthermore, as far as we know, this compound represents the first example in which four NCS- groups occupy the equatorial positions of a SCO [FeIIN6] chromophore, while the axial positions are occupied by a pyridine-like ligand. Usually, the opposite situation is the commonly observed in SCO complexes. Indeed, one should not expect SCO behavior for a {FeII(NCS)4(pyridine-like)} n  moiety because the ligand field strength of the NCS- is smaller than that of common pyridine-like ligands, and hence the HS state should be the ground state at all temperatures. This is particularly true for 4,4'bipy; for example, the 1D compound [FeII(4,4'bipy)(bt)(NCS)2] combining a bridging 4,4'bipy with the medium-strong α-diimine bidentate ligand 2,2'-bithiazoline (bt) and two cis-NCS- anions remains essentially HS at all temperatures. Similarly, in the 2D coordination polymer [Fe(4,4'bipy)2(NCS)2]⋅nSolvent the FeII is equatorially surrounded by four bridging 4,4'bipy ligands and two terminal trans-NCS- groups but remains HS for a representative series of solvents and even the unsolvated derivate. The HS persists when increasing the ligand field strength replacing NCS- with the [Ag(CN)2]- anion to form the Hofmann-like 3D coordination polymer {FeII(4,4'bipy)2[Ag(CN)2]2}. The only exception in this series corresponds to the [Fe(4,4'bipy)2(NCX)2]⋅nSolvent system when nSolvent = 4CHCl3. For X = S the compound displays a cooperative two-step transition in the interval of temperatures 80-160 K, while for X = Se only a half cooperative SCO occurs centered at ca. 160 K. The presence of four densely packed CHCl3 molecules around the FeII sites provides enough chemical pressure to observe SCO in both derivatives. Similarly, we invoke the occurrence of an effective ligand field strength stemming from the rigid and densely packed layers to explain the observation of SCO in 1. On one hand, the resulting strong elastic interaction may induce mechanical frustration responsible for the formation of long-range order HS and LS states of different molecular volume. On the other hand, the thermal contraction increases the molecular packing and drives ligand ordering.

elements.content: The title compound shows an unusual response to thermal and light stimuli, associated with six different phases with different HS fractions and different symmetry breaking due to spin state ordering and/or ligand ordering. When the complex moves from the HS phase 1 (γHS = 1, high symmetry) state to the commensurate SSCW phase 2 (γHS ≈ 1/2) the unit cell doubles to host two crystallographically distinct FeII centers, one HS and other LS. In this commensurate state the HS and LS centers are segregated in the crystal forming a SSCW corresponding to a periodic alternation of HS and LS stripes. By contrast, at slightly lower temperatures the subsequent step toward the incommensurate phase 3 (γHS ≈ 1/3) involves another SSCW with a periodicity incommensurate with the molecular lattice. This incommensurate state is erased at 90 K when the system attains the LS1 phase 4, (γHS ≈ 0) characterized by a unit cell equivalent to that described at 220 K but with smaller dimensions due to thermal compression and spin conversion. However, upon further cooling, doubling of this unit cell occurs and a low symmetric LS2 phase 5 appears. Interestingly, the photogenerated metastable HS* phase 6 retains this low symmetry, thus generating a phase distinct from the HS state observed at thermal equilibrium. This underlines the possibility to generate by light false ground states, which are never reached at thermal equilibrium. Examples of photoinduced polymorphism have been described for {FeII[H2B­(pz)2]2phen} and [FeIIH2L2Me]­(PF6)2 ([H2B­(pz)2]− = hydrobis-pyrazolylborate; phen = 1,10-phenanthroline; H2L2Me = bis [N-(2-methylimidazol-4-yl) methylidene-3 aminopropyl] ethylenediamine).

elements.content: A common denominator in the whole sequence of phase transitions observed for 1 is the change of twist angle ϕ of the crystallographically different 4,4′-bipy ligands () on the Fe sites. When 1 changes from the HS state to the commensurate HS:LS (phase 2) and subsequently to the incommensurate ≈2LS:HS (phase 3), the 4,4′-bipy losses the inversion symmetry. By contrast, the Hg-4,4′-bipy-Hg moiety remains centrosymmetric in the HS (phase 1), HS:LS (phase 2) and LS1 (phase 4) states but ϕ′ dramatically increases in the ≈2LS:HS (phase 3), LS2 (phase 5), and HS* (phase 6) states. These changes in ϕ and ϕ′ reflect the way in which the layers accommodate the structural modification of the [FeN6] centers.

By contrast, the Hg-4,4'-bipy-Hg moiety remains centrosymmetric in the HS (phase 1), HS:LS (phase 2) and LS1 (phase 4) states but ϕ' dramatically increases in the ~2LS:HS (phase 3), LS2 (phase 5), and HS* (phase 6) states. These changes in ϕ and ϕ' reflect the way in which the layers accommodate the structural modification of the [FeN6] centers.

elements.content: It is well-known that entropy plays an important role in such transformations. The HS state is favored at high temperature with respect to the LS state of lower entropy, and SCO occurs at thermal equilibrium from LS to HS states as temperature rises. This is described by the thermal evolution of the HS fraction γHS, which is a totally symmetric order parameter. But this is also true for structural aspects: high symmetry states are also favored at high temperature with respect to low symmetry states of lower entropy. The appearance of different orders can be described in the Landau theory of phase transition by nonzero symmetry breaking order parameters. The first order parameter, η, describes both HS/LS and ligand order in phase 2 (η ≠ 0 between 108 and 125 K). The structural order in phase 3, related to ligand and spin-state order, is described by another order parameter, λ (λ ≠ 0 only in phase 3, between 96 and 108 K). The ligand order in phase 5 is due to another type of cell doubling and a third symmetry breaking order parameter, μ (μ ≠ 0 in phase 5 and 6). Therefore, the phase diagram is very complicated to describe since γHS is strongly coupled to the three different symmetry breaking order parameters. The different phases associated with different order parameters compete.

elements.content:
Phase 1: γHS = 1, η = 0, λ = 0 and μ = 0

Phase 2: γHS ≈ 0.5, η ≠ 0, λ = 0 and μ = 0

Phase 3: γHS ≈0.34, η = 0, λ ≠ 0 and μ = 0

Phase 4: γHS = 0, η = 0, λ = 0 and μ = 0

Phase 5: γHS = 0, η = 0, λ = 0 and μ ≠ 0

Phase 6: γHS = 1, η = 0, λ = 0 and μ ≠ 0

The appearance of different phases and the corresponding phase transitions can be described through the complex development of the nonequilibrium free energy F = a 1 γ HS + a 2 γ HS 2 + b 1 η 2 + c 1 γ HS η 2 + c 2 γ HS λ 2 + c 3 γ HS μ 2 + d 1 μ 2 h 2 + d 2 μ 2 λ 2 + d 2 η 2 λ 2 + ... as done for the more simple case where a single intermediate HS–LS phase appears. The phase diagram becomes then multidimensional and difficult to describe. However, we can describe experimentally the different types of phase transitions. A phase transition from a low-symmetry LS state (phase 5) to high symmetry LS state (phase 4) occurs as the temperature rises, but in a temperature range (<95 K) where the LS state is stable. At higher temperature the HS state is favored and the crossover occurs, in steps because of elastic frustration. But the phase transition from a low symmetry HS to a high symmetry HS state is not observed at thermal equilibrium because the low symmetry HS state is not stable at high temperature. It is only observed after LIESST below 50 K, where the ligands order in the metastable HS state. It is therefore the competition between the different types of orders, involving both spin-state order and ligand order, which is responsible for the multistability and the formation of the six different phases observed here.

Phase 6: γHS = 1, η = 0, λ = 0 and μ ≠ 0

The appearance of different phases and the corresponding phase transitions can be described through the complex development of the nonequilibrium free energy    F =   a   1     γ   HS   +   a   2       γ   HS     2   +   b   1     η   2   +   c   1     γ   HS     η   2   +   c   2     γ   HS     λ   2   +   c   3     γ   HS     μ   2   +   d   1     μ   2     h   2   +   d   2     μ   2     λ   2   +   d   2     η   2     λ   2   + ...   as done for the more simple case where a single intermediate HS-LS phase appears. The phase diagram becomes then multidimensional and difficult to describe. However, we can describe experimentally the different types of phase transitions. A phase transition from a low-symmetry LS state (phase 5) to high symmetry LS state (phase 4) occurs as the temperature rises, but in a temperature range (<95 K) where the LS state is stable. At higher temperature the HS state is favored and the crossover occurs, in steps because of elastic frustration. But the phase transition from a low symmetry HS to a high symmetry HS state is not observed at thermal equilibrium because the low symmetry HS state is not stable at high temperature. It is only observed after LIESST below 50 K, where the ligands order in the metastable HS state. It is therefore the competition between the different types of orders, involving both spin-state order and ligand order, which is responsible for the multistability and the formation of the six different phases observed here.

elements.content: Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data were recorded for single crystals and microcrystalline samples of 1 at scanning rates 0.3, 0.5, and 1 K/min with a Quantum Design MPMS2 SQUID susceptometer equipped with a 7 T magnet, operating at 1 T and at temperatures 2–400 K. Experimental susceptibilities were corrected from diamagnetism of the constituent atoms by the use of Pascal’s constants. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 5700 spectrometer in the range 4000–400 cm–1. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) were performed using a LECO CHNS-932 analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Methods

Experimental Section

General

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data were recorded for single crystals and microcrystalline samples of 1 at scanning rates 0.3, 0.5, and 1 K/min with a Quantum Design MPMS2 SQUID susceptometer equipped with a 7 T magnet, operating at 1 T and at temperatures 2-400 K. Experimental susceptibilities were corrected from diamagnetism of the constituent atoms by the use of Pascal's constants. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 5700 spectrometer in the range 4000-400 cm-1. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) were performed using a LECO CHNS-932 analyzer.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data at 220 K, 117 K, 102 K, 90 K, 80 K, 15 K, and 15 K under irradiation for 1 were collected on an Oxford Diffraction Xcalibur3 using MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for three different crystals. The changes of the unit cell volume and cell parameters have been investigated during sample heating and cooling modes on the same crystal at the scanning rate of ∼0.1 K/min (Figures S1 and S3). We used an Oxford Cryosystems nitrogen-flow cryostat for measurements at low temperature down to 80 K and Helijet helium-flow cryostat for measurements at 15 K. The difference in thermal behavior between X-ray and magnetism data is due to kinetics effects. No sample fatigue or memory has been identified. In addition, no HS state trapping of 1 has been observed down to 80 K. A data scaling and empirical or multiscan absorption correction was performed with CrysAlisPro software by Rigaku Oxford Diffraction. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXT and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using SHELXL-97 with the exception of the phase 3 at 102 K. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. H atoms were constrained by geometry. When applicable, SIMU and ISOR restrains as well EADP constraints were applied for occupational disorder. For the aperiodic structure at 102 K, further least-squares refinement on F were performed with JANA2006. This refinement considers modulation of the atomic positions for all non-H atoms. The modulation of the selected geometry parameters along the superspace coordinate x 4 for incommensurate were calculated in 3D space of P1 cell based on a set of refined modulation parameters for system 1. The results were visualized and extracted by the use of Grapht tool of Jana2006.

elements.content: Compound 1 was obtained by diffusion in three-arms H-type vessels. One side of the vessel contained an aqueous solution (2 mL) of FeCl2 (0.10 mmol, 12.7 mg), while the middle arm contained a water solution of K2[Hg­(SCN)4] (2 mL) prepared in situ by mixing Hg­(SCN)2 (0.1 mmol) and KSCN (0.2 mmol). The other side of the vessel contained a methanol solution (2 mL) of 4,4′-bipy (0.10 mmol, 15.6 mg). The three-arms were filled with methanol, sealed and left in a quiet place. Light-orange block-like crystals of 1 suitable for single crystal X-ray analysis were obtained after about 1 week. M w 1117.87; yield ca. 45 mg (ca. 40%); IR (cm–1, room temperature). The most striking feature of the IR spectrum is a intense multiple band with peaks at 2147, 2138, and 2121 cm–1 and two less intense shoulder at 2095 and 2070 cm–1, which corresponds to the ν­(CN) stretching modes of the distinct NCS– groups (see Figure S6, Supporting Information). Anal. Found C 27.46, H 1.41, N 12.28; Calcd for C26H16FeHg2N10S6, C 27.94, H 1.44, N 12.53.

Materials

Metal Complex Synthesis

Compound 1 was obtained by diffusion in three-arms H-type vessels. One side of the vessel contained an aqueous solution (2 mL) of FeCl2 (0.10 mmol, 12.7 mg), while the middle arm contained a water solution of K2[Hg(SCN)4] (2 mL) prepared in situ by mixing Hg(SCN)2 (0.1 mmol) and KSCN (0.2 mmol). The other side of the vessel contained a methanol solution (2 mL) of 4,4'-bipy (0.10 mmol, 15.6 mg). The three-arms were filled with methanol, sealed and left in a quiet place. Light-orange block-like crystals of 1 suitable for single crystal X-ray analysis were obtained after about 1 week. M w 1117.87; yield ca. 45 mg (ca. 40%); IR (cm-1, room temperature). The most striking feature of the IR spectrum is a intense multiple band with peaks at 2147, 2138, and 2121 cm-1 and two less intense shoulder at 2095 and 2070 cm-1, which corresponds to the ν(CN) stretching modes of the distinct NCS- groups (see Figure S6, Supporting Information). Materials

Metal Complex Synthesis

Compound 1 was obtained by diffusion in three-arms H-type vessels. One side of the vessel contained an aqueous solution (2 mL) of FeCl2 (0.10 mmol, 12.7 mg), while the middle arm contained a water solution of K2[Hg(SCN)4] (2 mL) prepared in situ by mixing Hg(SCN)2 (0.1 mmol) and KSCN (0.2 mmol). The other side of the vessel contained a methanol solution (2 mL) of 4,4'-bipy (0.10 mmol, 15.6 mg). The three-arms were filled with methanol, sealed and left in a quiet place. Light-orange block-like crystals of 1 suitable for single crystal X-ray analysis were obtained after about 1 week. M w 1117.87; yield ca. 45 mg (ca. 40%); IR (cm-1, room temperature). The most striking feature of the IR spectrum is a intense multiple band with peaks at 2147, 2138, and 2121 cm-1 and two less intense shoulder at 2095 and 2070 cm-1, which corresponds to the ν(CN) stretching modes of the distinct NCS- groups (see Figure S6, Supporting Information). Anal. Found C 27.46, H 1.41, N 12.28; Calcd for C26H16FeHg2N10S6, C 27.94, H 1.44, N 12.53.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal dependence of χM T product (χM = magnetic susceptibility, T = temperature) of 1 is shown in a. In the interval 300–190 K, χM T ≈ 3.67 cm3 K mol–1 is practically constant and consistent with a FeII HS (S = 2) (phase 1). Below 170 K, χM T drops rapidly in a first step, reaching a first plateau in the temperature interval 125–108 K. On the plateau ca. 50% of HS → LS conversion (χM T ≈ 1.90 cm3 K mol–1 at 119 K) takes place (phase 2). On cooling further, a second drop occurs and another plateau is reached in the interval 108–96 K, which corresponds almost to ca. 66% of conversion (χM T ≈ 1.33 cm3 K mol–1) (phase 3). Finally, a third sharp drop occurs around 96 K and attains a value of χM T ≈ 0.1 cm3 K mol–1 at 93 K where the conversion toward the LS state is almost complete (phase 4). The heating mode reproduces the three steps, but the two low-temperature transitions occur at T c’s ca. 4–6 K higher than in the cooling mode (two cycles performed at scan temperature rates of 0.5 and 1 K min–1). This three-step transition corresponds rather well to the sequence [0HS:1LS] ↔ ≈ [1HS:2LS] ↔ [1HS:1LS] ↔ [1HS:0LS]. It is worth stressing that this magnetic behavior is perfectly reproducible after a great number of cycles and that the samples (single crystals) are very stable.

Photogeneration of the metastable HS* state at low temperature, the so-called light induced excited spin state trapping experiment (LIESST), was carried out on a microcrystalline sample (2.76 mg) of 1 (a). The sample was cooled down to 10 K where χM T ≈ 0.09 cm3 K mol–1. Then the sample was irradiated with red light (λ = 633 nm) rapidly attaining (less than 30′) a saturation χM T value ca. 3.0 cm3 K mol–1. Light irradiation was then switched off, and the temperature increased at a rate of 0.3 K min–1. In the 10–38 K temperature range χM T increased up to a maximum value ca. 3.40 cm3 K mol–1 at 38 K, which reflects thermal population of the different microstates arising from the zero-field splitting of the HS* (S = 2) state and suggests that the light-induced population of the HS* state is virtually complete at 10 K (phase 6). At temperatures greater than 39 K, χM T drops rapidly and reaches a value about 0.09 cm3 K mol–1 at ca. 62 K indicating complete HS* → LS relaxation. The T LIESST temperature determined from the maximum variation of χM T in the HS → LS relaxation is equal to 54 K.

Phase 4, γHS ≈ 0, LS1 Structure

The crystal structure in the LS state has been investigated at 90 K, 80 K, and 15 K. At 90 K the crystal remains triclinic with a (a,b,c) cell similar to the one of the HS phase: the total volume contraction of the unit cell ΔV c in the 220–90 K interval is 41.45 Å3 (Figure S1). This value corresponds to the sum of the volume change due to thermal expansion (ΔV(T) ≈ V HS·αV·T) and SCO (ΔV SCO). From the thermal dependence of the unit cell volume in the temperature range 172–250 K, where γHS is constant and ≈1, the volumetric thermal expansion coefficient, αv = (1/V)­(∂V∂T), is estimated to be in the interval 1.4–1.8 × 10–4 K–1 and then ΔV SCO is about 28.2 Å3 (see thermal variation of the cell volume and lattice parameters a, b, and c both in cooling and heating modes respectively in Figures S1 and S3). These values correspond well with what it is expected for a complete HS–LS transformation for one FeII center (LS1 state). The structure consists of a single Fe site, and its average Fe–N bond length <Fe1–N> = 1.961(3) Å and the angular distortion (Σoct)1 = 7.6° and the overall Δd(Fe–N) = 0.197(3) Å bond length change upon SCO are fully consistent with a LS state. Apart from these changes, the 90 K structure does not present other relevant differences with respect to the structure at 220 K (Figure S4). For example, (i) at both temperatures the assymmetric unit is the same; (ii) both crystallographically distinct 4,4′-bipy bridging ligands become again planar, ϕ = ϕ′ = 0; (iii) the deviation from 180° of the NCS– groups decreases a little being the largest separation 2.7° for S1–C6–N2; (iv) the tilt angle of the Fe-NCS moiety is smaller by ca. 2°; and (v) Σtet for Hg is virtually the same (75.7°). Similarly, the interaction between two consecutive layers is only modified a little: C8···C8i = 3.432(6) Å, C8···C13i = 3.661(6) Å, C8···C12i = 3.571(6) Å, and C6···S2i = 3.485(6) Å.
